page.title: Arts and Humanities in Higher Education

revision.comment: Fix [[:Category:Pages using deprecated image syntax]]; [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Briarcliff Farm|the mansion in Druid Hills, Georgia|Briarcliff (mansion)}} {{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} [[File:Images from Our Village, Briarcliff Manor 21.JPG|thumb|upright=1.5|alt=Cattle, a large barn, and silo; a large hotel on a hill in the background|Barn C on Dalmeny Road in front of the [[Briarcliff Lodge]],<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=23}} one of four cattle barns on the farm]]
'''Briarcliff Farms''' was a farm established in 1890 by [[Walter William Law]] in [[Briarcliff Manor]], a village in [[Westchester County, New York]]. One of several enterprises established by Law at the turn of the 20th century, the farm was known for its milk, butter, and cream and also produced other dairy products, [[American Beauty rose]]s, bottled water, and print media. At its height, the farm was one of the largest dairy operations in the [[Northeastern United States]], operating about {{convert|8000|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}} with over 1,000 [[Jersey cattle]]. In 1907, the farm moved to [[Pine Plains (town), New York|Pine Plains]] in New York's [[Dutchess County]], and it was purchased by New York banker [[Oakleigh Thorne]] in 1918, who developed it into an [[Angus cattle]] farm. After Thorne's death in 1948, the farm changed hands several times; in 1968 it became Stockbriar Farm, a beef feeding operation. Stockbriar sold the farmland to its current owners in 1979.
The farm combined a practical American business model with the concept of a European country seat or [[manor]], with cows being milked constantly, and with milk promptly chilled and bottled within five minutes, and shipped to stores in New York City each night. The farm was progressive, with sterile conditions, numerous employee benefits, good living conditions for livestock, and regular veterinary inspections to maintain a healthy herd. The farm also made use of [[tenant farming]], established working blacksmith, [[wheelwright]], and harness shops on-site, was located around Walter Law's [[manor house]], and constructed numerous buildings in the [[Tudor Revival]] architectural style.
Briarcliff Farms was the original location for the School of Practical Agriculture and Horticulture, established by the New York State Committee for the Promotion of Agriculture in conjunction with Walter Law. The school's purpose was to teach students in farming, gardening, poultry-keeping, and other agriculture-related skills. The school moved to a farm near [[Poughkeepsie]] in 1903, and the school building was run as a hotel for two years until it became Miss Knox's School. After the building burned down in 1912, Miss Knox's School was relocated several times; since 1954, the Knox School has been located in [[St. James, New York]].
==History== [[File:Stillman Farm in Briarcliff Manor.jpg|thumb|alt=Illustration of a farm and farmhouse buildings|Illustration of James Stillman's Briarcliff Farm around 1886]] James Stillman owned a small farm on Pleasantville Road since at least 1886.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=9, 12}} It was known as Briarcliff Farm after John David Ogilby's estate, Brier Cliff (itself named after Ogilby's family home in Ireland).<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|pages=21, 31}}<ref name="ButterTests"/> In 1887 Stillman had a display at the Great Dairy and Cattle Show in New York City's [[Madison Square Garden]], where he demonstrated setting milk, churning cream and making butter.<ref name="StillmanMSG"/> In 1890, Walter Law began purchasing property in the present-day village of Briarcliff Manor as part of his desire for rest and recreation.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> That year, Law paid James Stillman $35,000 (${{inflation|US|35000|1890|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) for his {{convert|236|acre|ha|adj=on}} farm and renamed it Briarcliff Farms.<ref name="1939history"/> In 1893, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that the [[Cristobal Colón y de La Cerda, 14th Duke of Veragua|14th Duke of Veragua]] (a [[livestock]] farmer) and a large party visited the farm on the afternoon of June 16; at that time, the farm had about 330 cattle and 100 sheep. The party went from New York to [[Scarborough, New York|Scarborough]], proceeding by carriage to Briarcliff, and visited the farm's poultry yard, hennery and stables. After observing the farm's heifers and stallions, they went to the creamery to taste Briarcliff butter. The guests went to Law's Yonkers home, Hillcrest, for dinner before returning to New York. After the visit, the duke had said "Well, this is a perfect place. I am delighted with what I have seen."<ref name="Duke"/> [[File:WalterWLaw1910.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.7|alt=An old man with white hair and sideburns wearing a suit|[[Walter W. Law|Walter Law]], founder of Briarcliff Farms and Manor]] In 1898 Law retired from the vice-presidency of [[W. & J. Sloane]], moved with his family to the area and began devoting his time to agriculture.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=35}} He rapidly added to his holdings, buying about forty parcels in less than ten years; by 1900, Law owned more than {{convert|5000|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}} of Westchester County<ref name="glassglory"/><ref name="society"/> and was its largest individual landholder.<ref name="Holdings"/> Some previous owners became [[tenant farmer]]s; Law received half of the hay and straw from a {{convert|160|acre|ha|sigfig=1|adj=on}} farm formerly owned by Jesse Bishop, and one-third of everything else.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=35}} Law and Briarcliff Farms initially deepened the [[Pocantico River]] for {{convert|2|mi|km|sigfig=1}}, taking out [[Ford (crossing)|rifts]] so the stream would flow and adjacent swamps would drain. Workers also cut rock and took out trees lining the swamps to reclaim land for farming.<ref name="Social1"/>
Law found the soil poor, since it had been farmed for a half-century. The fields were bare, and cows gave poor-quality milk: "I had to begin at the bottom and repair the waste of fifty years." He improved the soil's fertility by arranging for manure from New York City streets and stables to be regularly brought to his farm; for four years, twenty carloads of manure a week were spread on the land. As a result, the farm's hay yield increased from two to five tons. Law also decided to improve the area's roads, giving them a base layer of large, closely packed stones and layers of top gravel. He developed his herd; at first the farm had weak cattle (many afflicted with [[tuberculosis]]) and "ordinary milk", but after Law's development the farm had strong cattle, healthy calves and an abundance of rich milk. Law hired Leonard Pearson (a professor of [[veterinary medicine]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]])<ref name="Social1"/><ref name="WorldsWork"/> to check each cow every six months for tuberculosis<ref name="Nurses"/>{{rp|page=102}} and other diseases, exceeding [[New York City Board of Health]] standards.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/>
{{multiple image |align=right|total_width=375|footer=Briarcliff Table Water bottle (''left'') and a company wagon in front of the [[New York Public Library]], 1908 (''right'') |image1=BriarcliffTableWaterBottle.png|alt1=A pale blue glass bottle |image2=New York Public Library 1908-alt2.jpg|alt2=A monochrome photograph of the front of the New York Public Library's main branch }} Although Law had little knowledge or experience of farming at first, he had enough money to reach his goal of maximizing his dairy farm's quality and output.<ref name="RiverJournal"/> Law's farm had 500 workers tending cattle, pigs, chickens, [[Thoroughbred]] horses, pheasants, peacocks and sheep at its peak.<ref name="OssHist"/> In 1900, when the US government asked Briarcliff Farms to exhibit its milk, butter and cream at Paris' [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle]],<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=23}}<ref name="Co-operative"/> the farm submitted [[raw milk|raw]], pasteurized, and sterilized milk; however, according to the French, "There is no use sending these, for your fresh milk keeps fresh".<ref name="Social1"/> The farm contributed to the [[USDA]] [[Bureau of Animal Industry]] and the New York State Commission to the Paris Exhibition's joint exhibit,<ref name="ParisExpo1"/> winning gold medals for its milk, cream, and butter<ref name="ParisExpo2"/> and a silver medal for social benefit or economy.<ref name="Social4"/><ref name="Silver"/> Concerned that the farm's milk had preservatives, French authorities requested an [[affidavit]] that no chemicals were added.<ref name="Co-operative"/> Photographs by the US government of Briarcliff Farms' barns, farmland, Law's mottoes and employees were displayed<ref name="Conservative"/> in the exposition's Palace of Social Economy and Congress.<ref name="Social1"/>
On September 2, 1901, the farm's dairy buildings were destroyed by fire. The cause of the fire (which was discovered in the dairy building's tower) was unknown, and the damage was covered by insurance. Law quickly arranged for a temporary dairy in a room of the electric plant which had a boiler for sterilization; by the afternoon, milk was processed as usual. A larger dairy building was planned closer to the railroad station for faster shipping.<ref name="Social3"/>
When Briarcliff Manor was incorporated on November 21, 1902, Law owned all but two small parcels of the square-mile village and employed nearly all of its residents (around 100).<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=19}} He developed the village, establishing schools, churches, parks and the Briarcliff Lodge. The population grew, encouraging Law to incorporate the area as a village. A proposition was presented to the supervisors of Mount Pleasant and Ossining on October 8, 1902 that a {{convert|640|acre|ha|adj=on}} area with a population of 331 be incorporated as the Village of Briarcliff Manor,<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=14}} and it was incorporated on November 21.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=43}}<ref name="pamphlet"/> That year Law's son, [[Walter W. Law, Jr.|Walter Jr.]], joined his father and brother Henry in managing the farm and realty company; he was the second village president,<ref name="Walter Jr"/> in office from 1905 to 1918.<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=15}}{{refn|group=nb|The title changed to President-Mayor during Henry Law's office (1918-36) and subsequently to Mayor around 1936.<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=15}}}}
In April 1906, [[Governor General of Canada]] [[Albert Grey, 4th Earl Grey|Albert Grey]] and US Representative and farm architect [[Edward Burnett]] drove up from New York City and toured the farm as guests of Walter Law. According to ''Briarcliff Outlook'', they "expressed hearty approval of Briarcliff ways".<ref name="OutlookAp1906"/>{{rp|page=358}} <!--In November 1906, one of Briarcliff Farms' stores in New York City filled a large order of milk and cream for the battleship [[USS Louisiana (BB-19)|USS ''Louisiana'']] for President [[Theodore Roosevelt]]'s trip to the Panama Canal site.<ref>Briarcliff Once-A-Week, October 14, 1906, p34 https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066586292</ref>-->
===Relocation to Pine Plains=== [[File:Briarcliff Farms, Pine Plains.jpg|thumb|alt=A large barn and silos|Barn A in Pine Plains around 1910]] Law developed his Briarcliff Manor property primarily as a corporation until 1907 when, due to rising property values and falling agricultural development in Westchester County, he purchased twelve farms—totaling {{convert|3249|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}}—for Briarcliff Farms on both sides of the Pine Plains-Stanford Road (present-day [[New York State Route 82]]) in [[Pine Plains (town), New York|Pine Plains]]<ref name="LittleNine"/> and began developing his Briarcliff Manor properties for houses, churches and schools. Law's general manager, George W. Tuttle (who had worked at Briarcliff Farms since 1901),<ref name="LittleNine"/> arranged the Pine Plains purchases and the construction of new barns, a creamery, a [[power station]] and other buildings.<ref name="Register"/> The barns used [[Franklin Hiram King]]'s King ventilation system, and the concrete dairy building cost about $25,000 (${{Inflation|US|25000|1909|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}). The farm's well, {{convert|700|ft}} from the barn, was {{convert|26|ft}} deep and {{convert|15|ft}} in diameter.<ref name="NYSDA"/>
In 1907 and 1908, the farm and many of its workers moved to Pine Plains. Although preliminary steps in the relocation were primarily small, the final October 1908 transfer used two trains to move 300 cattle. The rest of the cattle were transferred a day later, to the farm's main station (between Pine Plains and [[Attlebury]] on the Central New England Railway)<ref name="CNEstop"/> at Barn A.<ref name="OutlookOc1908"/>{{rp|page=22}} During Briarcliff Manor's [[Briarcliff Manor, New York#Sports|first automobile race]] in 1908, the barns were used for mechanic crews and each driver had his own crew weeks before the race.<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=12}} In 1909 Law formed the Briarcliff Realty Company to sell the original Briarcliff Manor property. He sold the Pine Plains property in 1918<ref name="LodgeBook"/> and died in 1924.<ref name="LawDeath"/> [[File:Briarcliff Farms stable in Pine Plains.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Long, light-colored barn with several towers and a silo with scaffolding|Barn B in Pine Plains around 1910]] <!--On April 27, 1913, at the former farm location in Briarcliff Manor, the old Barn A was destroyed in a large fire.{{refn|The barn was at the north end of Dalmeny Road, where St. Theresa's school is today, behind the farms office.}} The barn was next-door to Briarcliff's fire company headquarters, which was previously a blacksmith shop. The fire company's steam-operated pumper could not create enough pressure quickly enough to stop the fire, although the barn took enough time to burn to allow people to carry out much of its contents, including its thirty horses and most of its carriages.Pages 5 and Unknown, BMFD 2001 book--> On October 9, 1918,<ref name="LittleNine"/><ref name="AA"/> New York banker [[Oakleigh Thorne]]<ref name="S&S"/> and several partners purchased the {{convert|4200|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1|adj=on}} Briarcliff Farms property, cattle and dairy buildings<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=37}} for $500,000 (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|500000|1918}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}).<ref name="ThorneNYT"/> Thorne began breeding [[Aberdeen Angus]] cattle under the Briarcliff Farms name, and the farm remained well known for its beef.<ref name="LittleNine"/><ref name="Taconic"/> Thorne and W. Alan McGregor began the herd by importing cattle from Scotland in 1925, and enlarged it through breeding. The Aberdeen Angus industry became prominent in the United States due to Briarcliff Farms;<ref name="1982NewsP3"/> in 1955, about 95 percent of US Angus cattle were from Briarcliff stock.<ref name="95Angus"/>
Thorne hired William Harper Pew for Pew's knowledge of livestock bloodlines. At the time, the farm had over {{convert|5000|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}} and 1,000 purebred Aberdeen Angus cattle (the largest Aberdeen Angus herd in the country). Pew began eighteen Angus herds in [[Dutchess County]], and was a director of the [[American Angus Association]].<ref name="Pew"/> At the International Livestock Show in 1927, the farm had the International Grand Champion Female, and in 1930 it had the 1930 International Grand Champion Bull. Because of the 1931 and 1933 expositions, Thorne became first to win a grand champion twice, with two of his livestock awarded International Grand Champion [[Cattle#Terminology|Steers]].<ref name="S&S"/> At the 1934 [[Dutchess County Fair]]'s beef-cattle show, 100 cattle and steers were exhibited. Briarcliff Aristocrat, a summer yearling weighing {{convert|1000|lb}}, was named the grand champion steer. The grand champion bull was the farm's Briarcliff Barbarian 8th, the first-prize senior yearling of the 1933 International Livestock Show. The grand champion female was Briarcliff Mighonne 10th, the first-prize senior yearling heifer of the 1933 international show.<ref name="AA"/><ref name="DutchessFair"/>
The farm affected a number of herds, and the Briarcliff prefix is still seen in many pedigrees.<ref name="AA"/> In 1935 the {{convert|2000|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1|adj=on}} portion of the farm east of the road was sold to Henry Jackson, who named it Bethel Farms. After Thorne's death in 1948, Briarcliff Farms changed hands a number of times. In 1968 it became Stockbriar Farm, a beef-feeding operation.<ref name="LittleNine"/> Stockbriar tried to sell the farm several times, and it nearly became a county zoo.<ref name="1982NewsP3"/> In 1979, Stockbriar sold the farmland to the Conservation and Preservation Association (CAPA) for $2.1 million (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|2100000|1979}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}).<ref name="1982News"/>
In 1982 CAPA hired a [[Millbrook, New York|Millbrook]] realtor, who advertised the farm for $2.75 million (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|2750000|1982}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) in ''The New York Times'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and newspapers published by Taconic Press.<ref name="1982News"/> Around that time Stockbriar Farms filed four lawsuits against CAPA and its lessee (Mashomack Fish and Game Preserve) over the Pine Plains farm, claiming that the preserve operated a private club without a liquor permit and CAPA missed a March 23, 1982 payment which was the bulk of its total payment for the farm.<ref name="1983News"/> Stockbriar Farms requested that Mashomack be evicted, and its property returned.<ref name="1982News"/> One lawsuit was filed in county court, and the other three were filed in [[New York Supreme Court]]. Although Mashomack and CAPA won the first two,<ref name="1982NewsP3"/> in 1984 a state supreme court justice ordered Mashomack and CAPA to vacate the property and Stockbriar Farms remained for sale.<ref name="1984News"/>
==Locations==
===Briarcliff Manor=== {{multiple image |align=right|total_width=350|footer=1360 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Farms' dairy and office, around 1900<ref name="BMSHSNews2014"/><ref name="1977history"/>{{rp|page=25}} |image1=Briarcliff Farms dairy 06.png|alt1=Monochrome photograph of farm buildings |image2=Briarcliff Farms dairy.jpg|alt2=Contemporary photograph of a half-timbered building }} The farm, overlooking the [[Hudson River]], was established between the Hudson and [[Pocantico River]]s in the hamlet of Whitson's Corners (present-day Briarcliff Manor), {{convert|27|mi|km|sigfig=1}} from [[Manhattan]]. Its location was described in 1901 as "the most healthy, hilly portion of Westchester ...where there are neither swamps nor contaminated streams of water".<ref name="Nurses"/>{{rp|page=101}} The original land plot, {{convert|4|mi|m|spell=in}} long and {{convert|3|mi|m|spell=in}} wide, was developed within twelve years.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> In 1901, Briarcliff Farms (including its school farm) encompassed {{convert|6000|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}} between Pleasantville and Old Briarcliff Roads north of Scarborough Road.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=31}} At its peak, its original location covered {{convert|7800|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}}.<ref name="Mashomack"/> In Briarcliff Manor, the farm had six main barns: Barn A, near its office building on Pleasantville Road, housed the horses for the farm and the [[Briarcliff Lodge]].<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=23}} The farm's blacksmith, wheelwright, harness shops and other buildings were located around that barn, and a [[smokehouse]] and butcher's shop were on-site.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} Barns B (housing 78 cattle) and C (housing 118 cattle) were at the south end of Dalmeny Road;<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=23}} Barn D (housing 116 cattle), between Beech Hill Road and [[New York State Route 117]], was later used as a boarding stable for horses. Barn E (housing 118 cattle) was on Pleasantville Road just east of the present [[Taconic State Parkway]], and Barn F (housing 118 cattle<ref name="1977history"/>{{rp|page=24}}) was in [[Millwood, New York|Millwood]] near the intersection of the Taconic and [[New York State Route 100]]. The farm also had a large barn near [[New York State Route 9A]] for supplies, including feed for the farm. Each barn had an ice shed to cool milk; ice was harvested primarily from Echo Lake (source of the Pocantico River), with Kinderogen Lake (now part of the [[Edith Macy Conference Center]]) as a supplemental source.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=35}} The farm had a large supply store, with feed and other items, southeast of the service station at North State and Pleasantville Roads.<ref name="1977history"/>{{rp|page=27}}
The Briarcliff Farms office, Walter Law's personal office, was also the first dairy building;<ref name="Leslie"/> it burned down in 1901, and was rebuilt the following year. From Briarcliff Manor's 1902 incorporation to the construction of its first municipal building in 1913, the office housed the village government.<ref name="BMSHSNews2014"/> During the 1960s the building was redesigned, rebuilt and became a local union headquarters for the [[International Union of Operating Engineers]].<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=16, 126}} The farm was enclosed, and its pastures were divided<ref name="IllAm"/> by stone walls from within the farm;<ref name="WorldsWork"/> the stones were also used for roadbeds, and for walls of the farm buildings, office, and Law's house.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}}<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=307}} [[File:BriarcliffFarmsHouses.jpg|thumb|alt=Three similar houses, with porches and garages|Cottages on Dalmeny Road]] Walter Law encouraged his Briarcliff Farms employees to move into the village, selling {{convert|2,500|sqft|adj=on}} or {{convert|11,250|sqft|adj=on}} plots of land to workers for a nominal price. He asked workers to choose the type of house they wanted; he would have it built and hold the mortgage,<ref name="WorldsWork"/> or allow them to rent a cottage.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=335}} Law built several wood-framed cottages near the farms,<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=23}} with steep [[Gablefront house|front-gable]] roofs and open porches using some of the first-floor space.<ref name="IfYou'reNYT"/> Of the cottages still standing, six are on Dalmeny Road and three are on Old Briarcliff Road.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=125}} The farm also owned and operated a farm in [[Peekskill]] previously owned by [[John Paulding]], a militiaman who helped capture British major [[John André]],<ref name="OutlookJu1905"/>{{rp|pages=29–30}} running the Peekskill farm as a nursery for maples, oaks, lindens, hemlocks, spruces and other trees.<ref name="OutlookAp1907"/>{{rp|page=587}} During the early 1900s Law purchased farms in [[Lewisboro]] and [[Pound Ridge]], using those farms to replenish the main farm's cattle herd. He also purchased a house in Pound Ridge, which his Briarcliff Realty Company sold to Westchester County after his death; it became the headquarters of the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, the county's largest park.<ref name="PoundRidge"/>
====Dalmeny==== {{multiple image |align=left|total_width=350|footer=The Dalmeny boarding house and its reading room |image1=Images from Our Village, Briarcliff Manor 20.JPG|alt1=A four-story residence |image2=Dalmeny Interior.jpg|alt2=A room with tables, chairs, and men seated }} Walter Law provided Dalmeny, a [[boarding house]] on Dalmeny Road,<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=36}} for the farm's single men.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> The building, modeled after the [[Mills House No. 1|Mills Houses]] in New York City,<ref name="Social4"/> was {{convert|100|ft}} long and four stories tall. Its first floor had a social hall for meetings and entertainment, a parlor and reading room equipped with books, newspapers, magazines, and games, a large dining room, a private dining room, a kitchen and a bathroom with marble basins and clean towels. The upper floors had seventy individual bedrooms for the men, with bathrooms with showers and tubs on every floor.<ref name="WorldsWork"/><ref name="Social2"/> Dalmeny also had a resident barber. Farm workers were not required to live in the boarding house, although the number of people wanting to live there exceeded the space available. Rent was $15–18 per month, including room, [[Room and board|board]] and laundry. Law frequently joined the men at meals,<ref name="WorldsWork"/> lecturers visited the boarding house<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=313}} and the farm workers had a performing orchestra, brass band and [[glee club]].<ref name="Social4"/><ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=335}}
Dalmeny opened on Christmas 1899<ref name="Social2"/> and closed in July 1908, in conjunction with the farm's relocation to [[Upstate New York]].<ref name="OutlookOc1908"/>{{rp|page=142}} Over a period of several months in 1909 the building was moved to the Briarcliff Lodge property, where it was adjacent to the Lodge's laundry building.{{refn|group=nb|The Briarcliff Lodge's laundry building was built in 1909, was [[The King's College (New York)|The King's College]]'s music building, and was demolished in summer 2002.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=90, 115}}}} When the Lodge was the campus of [[The King's College (New York)|King's College]] from 1955 to 1994, the school called the former boarding house Harmony Hall and used it for classrooms and staff housing.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=36, 90}} In autumn 1979, King's College demolished the building shortly after dedicating a new classroom building.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=90}}
===Pine Plains=== Briarcliff Farms' second location, in the [[Pine Plains (town), New York|town of Pine Plains]], initially covered {{convert|3249|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}}.<ref name="LittleNine"/> The farm, {{convert|2|mi|km|sigfig=1}} from the [[Pine Plains (CDP), New York|hamlet of Pine Plains]], was adjacent to the [[Central New England Railway]]<ref name="NYSDA"/> in the shallow Stissing Basin and {{convert|12|mi|km|sigfig=1}} from the Hudson River.<ref name="OutlookOc1908"/>{{rp|page=105}} The Pine Plains farm had three barns, each built at a cost of about $20,000 (${{Inflation|US|20000|1909|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) and housing 200 [[Jersey cattle]] bedded in sawdust or shavings.<ref name="NYSDA"/> Barn B was in the Pine Plains hamlet of Bethel<ref name="LittleNine"/><ref name="NYSDA"/> and Barn C was farther south, in the town of [[Stanford, New York|Stanford]].<ref name="LittleNine"/>
==Operations== {{Infobox nutritional value | name = Briarcliff Farms milk | lactose = 4.83 g | fat = 5.36 g | protein = 3.76 g | water = 85.31 g | ash = 0.47 g | note = <small>Source: "The Inspiration of a Great Farm", ''Country Life in America'', page 13, 1902.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/></small> | float = right }} [[File:Briarcliff Outlook.jpg|thumb|upright=0.6|alt=Magazine cover, with a bunch of daffodils|''Briarcliff Outlook'' cover, April 1906]] {{Historical populations |align=right|width=14em|shading=off|percentages=pagr |title=Briarcliff Farms herd population |pop_name={{abbr|No.|Number}} |1893|330 |1899|849 |1900|1029 |1901|1045 |1902|1100 |1904|2460 |1908|1200 |1915|900 |1918|1000 |footnote=Sources:{{Div col}}* 1893<ref name="Duke"/><br />* 1899<ref name="Social1"/>{{rp|page=10}}<br />* 1900<ref name="Social1"/>{{rp|page=10}}<br />* 1901<ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}}<br />* 1902<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=308}}<br />*1904<ref name="1977history"/>{{rp|page=17}}<br />*1908<ref name="NYP">{{cite book|title=The Finance and Commerce of New York and United States|publisher=[[The New York Tribune]]|page=240|url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008903697|date=1909|accessdate=February 28, 2016}}</ref><br />* 1915<ref name="Register"/><br />* 1918<ref name="ThorneNYT"/>{{Div col end}} }} The farm utilized the concept of a European country seat,<ref name="Social1"/> through [[tenant farming]],<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=35}} established blacksmith, [[wheelwright]], and harness shops on-site, in addition to a butcher shop and smokehouse.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} Buildings were centrally located around Walter Law's [[manor house]], many of which were constructed in the [[Tudor Revival]] style. The farm's office building,<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=16}} Dysart House,<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=15}} the Briarcliff Lodge,<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=15, 19}} and the railroad station<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=35}} shared that architectural style.
The farm, one of the first producers of certified milk in the US, operated under the supervision of the Milk Commission of the Medical Society of the County of New York.<ref name="NYSDA"/> With the farm producing about {{convert|4500|USqt|l|abbr=off}} of milk daily<ref name="WorldsWork"/> (an average of {{convert|8|USqt|l|abbr=off}} per cow per day),<ref name="NYSDA"/> Briarcliff Farms was one of the largest dairy operations in the northeast.<ref name="Mashomack"/> According to Nebraska's department of agriculture in 1903, the three largest owners of dairy cows in the eastern US were Fairfield Farm Dairy in New Jersey, Briarcliff Farms and the Walker-Gordon Laboratory Company (which had "branches in all of the principal cities").<ref name="Largest"/> In 1897 the farm had Jersey, [[Normande]] and [[Simmental cattle|Simmental]] cattle,<ref name="IllAm"/> selling the breeds' milk for 10, 12 and 15 cents per quart respectively. Briarcliff Farms also sold cream (with 50 percent [[butterfat]])<ref name="WorldsWork"/> for 60 cents per quart, Jersey butter for 50 cents per pound and Normande or Simmental butter for 60 cents per pound.<ref name="MilkVarieties"/> In 1909, half the farm's herd consisted of [[Breed registry|registered]] Jerseys and the other half high-grade Jerseys.<ref name="NYSDA"/> In Pine Plains, many of Barn B's milkers were from the [[Netherlands]] because of that country's reputation for good milkers.<ref name="LittleNine"/>
In 1905, Briarcliff Farms was milking nearly 500 cows at any given time. The farm raised its own stock, feeding the cattle eight pounds of dry feed twice a day<ref name="NYSDA"/> with pasture and green corn in summer. The feed mixture was 50 percent bran, 25 percent crushed oats and 25 percent cornmeal, all of which were claimed to be the best available. The farm required that each cow produce 6,000 pounds of milk with 5 percent butterfat or 5,000 pounds of milk with 6 percent butterfat, or she would be butchered or sold. Each cow ate an average of seven pounds of grain per day (varying from two pounds on pasture to 12 in winter), 1.5 to 2 pounds of oil meal each day and free-choice timothy and clover hay—{{convert|17|-|20|lb}} daily, depending on size. Each worker milked, cleaned and groomed 16 to 18 cattle daily. The New York Milk Commission analyzed the farm's milk weekly; although the board of health regulations in New York allowed three million bacteria per [[cubic centimeter]] in milk, the milk commission limited bacteria to 30,000. The farm chilled its milk within two minutes of milking to {{convert|45|°F|°C}}, often limiting its bacteria counts to 200–400 per cc.<ref name="OutlookSe1905"/>{{rp|pages=289–91}} A chemical analysis of the milk was performed every month;<ref name="MunJournal"/> although regulations required a minimum of three percent butterfat, Briarcliff required its milk to have over five percent butterfat to be sold.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> A March 1905 New York Milk Commission analysis indicated that the farm's milk had 8.2 percent butterfat, the "richest Briarcliff product ever reported on".<ref name="OutlookJu1904"/>{{rp|page=210}}
In 1901 the farm had 1,045 Jersey cattle, 4,000 chickens and ducks, 1,500 pigs, and 400 sheep.<ref name="WorldsWork"/><ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}} It grew, with 500 workers tending those animals in addition to [[Thoroughbred]] horses, pheasants and peacocks.<ref name="OssHist"/> The pigs (which included [[Chester White]]s and [[Berkshire pig|Berkshires]]) lived outdoors, because the farm superintendent believed they should be penned only for breeding; in summer, they were allowed to run in the orchards or the woods.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> About 2,000 were butchered each year.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} The farm's 31 poultry houses had a head poulterer and 40 assistants; each building was {{convert|18|by|100|ft}}, and they were spread around the property. The farm, which used 300-egg insulators,<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} fed the hens a mix of grains (including oats, wheat and corn) five times a day.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> The farm butchered 7,000 [[broiler]]s each season.<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> Eggs sold for 35 to 50 cents per dozen, with demand exceeding supply. Broilers sold for $1.50 (${{Inflation|US|1.5|1901|r=0|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) to $3.00 (${{Inflation|US|3|1901|r=0|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) per pair.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> Briarcliff Farms raised about 300 lambs each spring, primarily [[Dorset Horn]]s. The lambs, which were dressed (their internal organs removed) on the farm, sold for $12 (${{Inflation|US|12|1900|r=0|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) or more apiece; demand also exceeded supply.<ref name="WorldsWork"/><ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}}
The farm gardens grew a variety of crops, adapting to the market;<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> in 1900 this included oats, rye, corn, wheat, buckwheat, carrots, [[Mangelwurzel|mangolds]], turnips, rutabagas, radishes, sugar beets, potatoes, apples, cabbages, rye, oat, and wheat straw, hay, corn stalks and [[silage]].<ref name="Social1"/> The farm rotated its grain production to grow better vegetables. At one time the farm had {{convert|12|acre|sqmi|sigfig=1}} of asparagus,<ref name="WorldsWork"/> which sold for 35 to 50 cents per bunch.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=334}}
Briarcliff Farms operated a printing press and office north of the farm office on Pleasantville Road. The print shop produced ''Briarcliff Farms'', the ''Briarcliff Bulletin'' in 1900, the monthly ''Briarcliff Outlook'' in 1903 and ''The Briarcliff Once-a-Week'' in 1908 (all edited by Arthur W. Emerson)<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=27}} and bottle caps for Briarcliff dairy products. The Briarcliff Table Water Company sold its products in New York City, [[Lakewood, New Jersey]] and the Westchester municipalities of [[Yonkers]], [[Tarrytown, New York|Tarrytown]], [[White Plains, New York|White Plains]], and [[Ossining (town), New York|Ossining]]. The company owned {{convert|250|ft|m|adj=mid|-deep}} wells.<ref name="1977history"/>{{rp|page=27}} Around 1901, the Briarcliff Steamer Company No. 1 (later the [[Briarcliff Manor Fire Department]]) housed its equipment and horses at Briarcliff Farms' Barn A.<ref name="BMFDhistory"/>{{rp|page=5}} The American Plasmon Syndicate, a producer of the dried milk product plasmon, had its factory in Briarcliff for milk from Briarcliff Farms;<ref name="CountryLifeJun1902"/> the farm built the factory and its power plant.<ref name="Co-operative"/>
In a 1900 publication the farm's motto was reported to be "The production of pure food of the highest standard of excellence",<ref name="AmGardening"/> although a 1902 publication reported that its motto was "Do unto a cow as you would that a cow would do unto you" (also saying that the motto appeared in large letters in every barn on the farm).<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=309}} Notices printed by the farm began with the verse, "If a Cobbler by trade, I'll make it my pride, the best of all Cobblers to be; and if only a Tinker, no Tinker on earth shall mend an old Kettle like me";<ref name="WorldsWork"/> this verse and several other mottoes decorated [[frieze]]s on the interior walls of the Dalmeny boarding house.<ref name="Social1"/><ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=67}}
===Processing and delivery=== [[File:Briarcliff Farms bottling.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|alt=Two men in white, one arranging milk bottles|Bottling at Briarcliff Farms, 1906]] At its peak, the farm delivered milk to areas from [[Albany, New York|Albany]] to New York City.<ref name="Mashomack"/> After it was cooled, the milk was brought daily to the dairy-processing building,<ref name="OutlookAu1904"/> where it was poured into a large, sterilized tank and forced—with compressed air at {{convert|160|USqt}} per minute<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=312}}—through sterilized pipes to the building's second floor. There the milk was cooled, strained five times and bottled.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> The bottles were sealed with [[Parchment paper|parchment]] circles with the supervising commission's certification and the date,<ref name="NYSDA"/> and then put in boxes with ice.<ref name="MunJournal"/> The entire process, from entering the building to bottling, took five minutes. Every utensil contacting the milk (or workers) would be regularly sterilized with [[live steam]]. The building was as free of bacteria as the farm could make it; its rooms had white-tiled walls and floors, with coving (concave tiling) between the walls and floors for better cleaning.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> Milk bottles were reused after several cleanings with rotating wire brushes and two hours of heat sterilization.<ref name="MunJournal"/>
[[File:HotelMcAlpin-BriarcliffFarms.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|alt=Beverage menu with prices|Part of a [[Hotel McAlpin]] menu from 1917, with Briarcliff Farms milk offered by the bottle]] The farm's products were packaged as milk, cream, butter or [[Kumis|kumyss]], and sent every night on the [[New York and Putnam Railroad]] to New York City for delivery the next day;<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=26}}<ref name="OutlookAu1904"/> they were also sold in the farm's stores or from wagons.<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=312}} Briarcliff Farms had three stores in New York City and stores in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], Yonkers, [[Dobbs Ferry]] and [[Tarrytown]].<ref name="stores"/> The farm's first New York City store was in Manhattan's Windsor Arcade, at [[Fifth Avenue]] and 46th Street, and it had an office in the Seymour Building at [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]].<ref name="Advertisement"/> The office produced advertisements for the ''[[New-York Tribune]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[New York Evening Post]]'' and the ''[[Mail and Express]]'' (papers which, according to ''[[Printers' Ink]]'', advertised to wealthy residents).<ref name="Advertisement"/> The farm's stores sold Briarcliff dairy products and table water.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=36}} Milk was sent to the Hotel Lorraine, the [[St. Regis Hotel|St. Regis]], the [[Waldorf Astoria]], Mendel's Lunch Room at [[Grand Central Station]] {{sic}} and Milhau's Drug Store on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], and kumyss was sent to seventeen New York City drugstores. Milk was sold to stores in New York [[FOB (shipping)#North America|free on board]] for $0.084 (${{Inflation|US|0.084|1911|r=2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) per quart.<ref name="NYSDA"/> The farm also supplied the Briarcliff Lodge with cream, milk, butter, eggs and vegetables.<ref name="LodgeProducts"/> It shipped its products in zinc-lined cases on ocean-going steamers and shipped nationwide every day except Sunday (shipping a double order on Saturday).<ref name="OutlookAu1904"/>{{rp|page=278}} The farm's milk was processed into milk, cheese, butter or buttermilk at its Barn A creamery in Pine Plains, and packaged for its {{convert|101|mi|km|sigfig=1|adj=on}} rail shipment to New York City.<ref name="LittleNine"/>
===Ethos and advances=== {{Quote box|align=right|width=40%|fontsize=76%|quote=That a man ...who has acquired wealth by trade or manufacture should leave the city to develop an ideal farm is something new and notable. This is what Mr. Walter W. Law has done at Briarcliff Manor. He determined to have a farm run absolutely on the highest principles—a farm where science should speak the first word and the last word, and all the time. Science is nothing but accumulated experience; what we have found out to be best and truest; and so Briarcliff Manor farms were simply to do the best, instead of second best, or third best, or tenth best. The houses were to be models, the stables were to be ideal, the orchards planted and worked ideally, the gardens must show what possibly could be done in vegetables, and the corn crop and the oats and the wheat must not be left to any guesses of man or nature. Feeding must be done on scientific principles; barns must be as sanitary as houses; stables must be sunny and thoroughly ventilated. Water must be absolutely pure for the cattle, and their sanitary conditions as perfect as those for human beings.|source=''The Independent'' <ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}}}}
In 1906, [[Andrew Carnegie]] wrote about Briarcliff Farms: "Every known appliance or mode of treatment is at hand, and the herd is pronounced free from all and every ailment. In cases of doubt animals are sacrificed".<ref name="RiverJournal"/> The farm used the best obtainable stock, with extensive experimenting, for its products. The operation immediately removed every cow that appeared ill, and many cattle were butchered during the farm's first few years to improve the herd's overall health. According to Walter Law, "It is not the cows that have been put in, but those which have been taken out, that have made the Briarcliff herd what it is". The farm's large, light barns had concrete floors, which were cleaned daily,<ref name="MunJournal"/> and up-to-date appliances for separating, churning, handling and packing its products.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/>
Law made annual five-dollar cash awards (${{Inflation|US|5|1900|r=0|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) to workers in September (giving them out at Dalmeny on December 24),<ref name="Social1"/> which included "most gentle with cows", "most careful teamster in feeding his horses and keeping his stables clean", "cleanest delivery wagon", "neatest house yard", "best garden truck" and "best-kept room in Dalmeny";<ref name="WorldsWork"/> the farm emphasized the commercial value of such virtues. On Christmas Eve, after the Briarcliff Orchestra played [[George Frideric Handel]]'s "[[Ombra mai fu|Largo]]", Law spoke about the farm's improvements that year and awarded the prizes.<ref name="Social1"/> The orchestra was made up of the farm's workers, and among its members was Law's son [[Walter W. Law, Jr.|Walter Jr.]]<ref name="WorldsWork"/>
{{Quote box|align=right|width=40%|fontsize=76%|quote=The arrangement for human beings must be on the highest level. Men and boys who were employed must be looked after to produce a splendid human result. That is, they must not be left to act as so many mechanical appliances or brute force masters of the lower animals ... It seems not yet quite familiar to us that a store should have the [[Golden Rule]] for a business maxim; but what are we to make of a farm where the superintendent says, "Not until we apply the Golden Rule to cows will we ever get the best from them?" The walls of the stables are hung with such mottoes as "Speak gently; it is better far to rule by love than by fear." The application of this rule to cows ought to create a moral evolution in the stablemen, so that by and by it could be applied to human folk as well, and thoroughly believed in as a workable law of life.|source=''The Independent'' <ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}}}} Briarcliff Farms intended to prove that optimal farming practices could be profitable.<ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}} Law believed that kind treatment would produce better cattle, and was intolerant of animal abuse:<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=26}} "Cruelty to a cow is the same as cruelty to me, and shall never be permitted on this farm."<ref name="WorldsWork"/> He knew everyone who lived at the farms,<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=316}} and the farm workers knew the name of each cow<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=310}} (which was on a brass plate at the front of the cow's stall).<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} The cows were sponged several times a day, and workers wore white cotton suits which were sterilized daily by boiling. Law treated his workers as intelligent co-workers, rather than laborers.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> Each cow was groomed before milking, and a pail of warm water and a brush would then be used on her sides, flanks and udders. The flank and udder were washed again with a one-percent creolin solution, rinsed and dried.<ref name="NYSDA"/> Workers would milk into a fine wire strainer placed over a pail; during milking no talking, laughing, smoking or spitting was permitted, since such behavior was claimed to have a "perceptible effect upon their milk".<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}}<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=312}} The workers were required to wash their hands thoroughly after cleaning the udders and before milking each cow.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> Each worker had a set of towels and washed, cared for and milked 15 or 16 cows.<ref name="NYSDA"/> The cattle grazed from early spring until late autumn, and were in the barns only for milking. In 1901, ''The Trained Nurse and Hospital Review'' said it doubted that any other large New York-area dairy did this.<ref name="Nurses"/>{{rp|page=102}}
The farm had a veterinary chemist and a laboratory for regular milk analysis.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> Its dairy plant had a visitor-observation area,<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=336}} permitting the viewing of each step of the farm's dairy processing. In one room (separated from the viewing area by glass doors), cream was skimmed; in a second milk was bottled, and in a third butter was churned. The building's sterilizing, pasteurizing, and shipping departments were in the basement. Briarcliff Farms shipped {{convert|2000|USqt|l}} of milk, {{convert|300|USqt|l}} of cream and {{convert|500|lb|kg}} of butter each day.<ref name="Conservative"/> Students from the [[Ethical Culture School]] and nurses from New York City hospitals visited the farm to learn about its practices in relation to their work,<ref name="Nurses"/>{{rp|pages=102–3}} and Briarcliff Farms was reportedly chosen as the most typical New York industry available for inspection.<ref name="Excursion"/>
===Greenhouses=== {{Listen|type=music|filename=10 Briarcliff Rose.ogg|title=''Briarcliff Rose''|description=From [[Carmino Ravosa]]'s Briarcliff show}} [[File:Welcome to Briarcliff.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|alt=Briarcliff Manor welcome sign|The Briarcliff Rose on a village sign]] Although Briarcliff Farms' primary operation was dairy, a secondary agricultural product was its American Beauty rose. The farm had two groups of greenhouses; one, behind Walter Law's house and west of the Briarcliff Lodge, produced decorations for Briarcliff Farms, the Briarcliff Lodge and Law's and his workers' houses. The other group, the Pierson commercial greenhouses, grew the American Beauty rose and rare [[carnation]]s; it produced 22 varieties and about 2,500 blooms a day.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=26}}<ref name="WorldsWork"/> The greenhouses, advanced for their time, had light steel frames and glass panes unique in their "almost unshadowed exposure to the light". The newer greenhouses, {{convert|50|by|300|ft}},<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> held up to 40,000 plants apiece.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> The Pierson roses, which earned up to $100,000 (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|100000|1900}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) a year, were sold in winter for eight to 12 cents each<ref name="WorldsWork"/> with most shipped to New York City.<ref name="glassglory"/> The Briarcliff Lodge sponsored an annual American Beauty carnival with a golf tournament, water sports, moonlight bathing and night diving, a dinner dance, a cinema program and a concert.<ref name="Carnival"/>
Greenhouse foreman George Romaine propagated an American Beauty rose with longer, more-pointed buds and a brighter color, and Paul M. Pierson registered it with the American Rose Society as the Briarcliff Rose.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=37}} It is Briarcliff Manor's village symbol,<ref name="pamphlet"/> and since 2006 has been used on village street signs.<ref name="RoseStreetSigns"/> Although the Briarcliff Manor Garden Club also uses the Briarcliff Rose as its symbol,<ref name="GardenClub"/> the variety is now lost.<ref name="BMSHSNews2014"/>
==School of Practical Agriculture== [[File:Pocantico Lodge.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.2|alt=A three-story rectangular building on a hill|The school's first building]] During the winter of 1895-96, the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor<ref name="LivingIssues"/> researched the causes of youth moving from the country to cities to develop the most efficient method of attracting them back to the country.{{refn|group=nb|The inquiry was specifically made by George T. Powell and a Pennsylvania farmer named Kelgaard in New York City. The two asked state residents, primarily farmers, about urban migration, tenant farming, and principals of agriculture. The direct result of the research was the founding of the School of Practical Agriculture.<ref name="SPA-NYT"/>}} That, and an examination of agricultural needs for a year,<ref name="PracticalSchool"/> resulted in meetings at the homes of Abram S. Hewitt and R. Fulton Cutting and the formation of the New York State Committee for the Promotion of Agriculture.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> The committee, chaired by Hewitt, included Cutting, Jacob H. Schiff, John G. Carlisle, Mrs. Seth Low, Josephine Shaw Lowell, Walter Law and William E. Dodge. Its board of trustees had five officers (with Theodore L. Van Norden president) and seventeen other trustees, including Law, [[V. Everit Macy]] and [[James Speyer]].<ref name="NYTPoughkeepsie"/> George T. Powell,{{refn|group=nb|Powell was a practical educator and lecturer with Cornell University and the USDA.<ref name="Puritan"/>{{rp|page=338}}}} a "recognized authority on scientific agriculture" according to ''The New York Times'', was consulted; he later organized the school and became its director.<ref name="NYTPoughkeepsie"/> When Walter Law was included the school took shape,<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> since he provided its land and building.<ref name="SFCall"/> In September 1900,<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> Law and the committee established the School of Practical Agriculture and Horticulture as part of Briarcliff Farms, on an elevated {{convert|66|acre|ha|adj=on}} site about midway between the [[Briarcliff Manor Public Library|Briarcliff Manor]] and [[Pleasantville (Metro-North station)|Pleasantville]] train stations<ref name="Yonkers"/> on Pleasantville Road.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=10}} Law leased the 66 acres (which were worth $1,000 (${{Inflation|US|1000|1901|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) an acre) for 20 years at the rate of a dollar per year, gave the trustees $30,000 (${{Inflation|US|30000|1901|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) to build a dormitory and promised them $3,000 (${{Inflation|US|3000|1901|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) a year for expenses until the school earned a profit. With that and $30,000 from the trustees, the school opened;<ref name="WorldsWork"/> the committee focused the curriculum on [[horticulture]], [[floriculture]], gardening and [[aviculture]].<ref name="PracticalSchool"/> The school's progress was followed by members of the public interested in agricultural education.<ref name="USDA"/> [[File:SchoolofPracticalAgriculture.jpg|thumb|alt=Flower gardens surrounded by paths|The school's landscape gardens]] When it was founded, the school was considered an experiment.<ref name="USDA"/> Its goal was "to open an independent means of livelihood for young men and women, especially of our cities; to demonstrate that higher values may be obtained from land under intelligent management, and to develop a taste for rural life."<ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}} Most students were trained in garden and farm operations in a two-year course, with short summer courses in nature study also offered. The academic year had three terms, with twelve weeks of vacation. Although the school allowed new students to begin at any term, a September start was considered the most desirable.<ref name="AmGardening"/> Instruction was offered in [[agriculture]], horticulture, cold storage, [[botany]], chemistry, geology, physics, agricultural zoology, [[entomology]], [[beekeeping]],<ref name="AmGardening"/> [[meteorology]], land surveying and leveling, soils, drainage, irrigation, [[tillage]], fertilizers, plant diseases, stock, fruit growing, landscape gardening and bookkeeping. It was a practical school, with no attempt to provide a general education. Work included caring for orchard trees and bush fruit, greenhouse culture of fruits and vegetables, jelly- and jam-making, market gardening, tillage, fertilizer use, hybridizing and propagating flowers, harvesting and marketing crops. The school used Briarcliff Farms, where students worked the land, tested milk and cared for a variety of animals.<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> Students also raised flowers, vegetables and fruit, and accompanied their products to cities for marketing.<ref name="Leslie"/>{{rp|page=314}} The [[New York Botanical Garden]] arranged with the school for student access to its lectures, museums and conservatories.<ref name="WorldsWork"/> Tuition was $100 a year (${{Inflation|US|100|1901|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}), and [[Room and board|board]] $280 a year (${{Inflation|US|280|1901|r=-2|fmt=c}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}). Instruction was primarily weekday-morning lectures with laboratory work; during the afternoon, students worked on the school farm (which had a foreman, gardener and several workmen to ensure continuous operation)<ref name="USDA"/> under instructor supervision.<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> In 1901 35 students attended, followed by 34 in 1902<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> (almost all from cities), ranging in age from 16 to 35. Most had a high-school education before enrolling, and some had been to college. The school had a capacity of 35 students, and planned to expand.<ref name="USDA"/>
For one year it met in the basement of Pleasantville's public school (until the Briarcliff Farms building was completed), and did not provide housing.<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> The farm building was completed in spring 1901<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|page=18}} and dedicated on May 15.<ref name="Yonkers"/> The large [[Colonial Revival]] building, with a plain exterior and wide halls,<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> had lecture halls, a library, a laboratory,<ref name="CountryLifeMay1902"/> an office, a dining hall<ref name="Yonkers"/> and dormitory space for 40 staff members and students. Its grounds had an orchard, a working garden, experimental greenhouses, poultry houses, a farmhouse<ref name="USDA"/> and barns.<ref name="Independent"/>{{rp|page=2666}} The school's faculty included a director, a horticulturalist, an agriculturalist and instructors in nature study and cold storage. It was [[coeducational]], with identical courses for men and women.<ref name="SPA-NYT"/> Students were required to be proficient in English, provide good references, be at least 16 years of age, and be in good health.<ref name="USDA"/> On January 1, 1902 [[Henry Francis du Pont]], then in his third year at [[Harvard University]], wrote to Powell requesting admission to the school; Powell replied that DuPont was listed first in the school's 1903 class. However, DuPont was unable to attend and left Harvard (perhaps due to his mother's sudden death in autumn 1902).<ref name="HFDuPont"/>
===Relocation and closure=== The school outgrew its Briarcliff location,<ref name="ExpStation3"/> and in autumn 1902 R. Fulton Cutting purchased a {{convert|415|acre|ha|adj=on}} farm near Poughkeepsie as a permanent upstate location.<ref name="NYTPoughkeepsie"/> Prior to the move, the school was popularly known as the Briarcliff School, and after moving it became formally known as the School of Practical Agriculture at Poughkeepsie. When the school was established there, Theodore Van Norden said that it needed funds for equipment and an endowment.<ref name="SFCall"/> The land had no buildings, and thus the school rented two houses in Poughkeepsie until funds were obtained to build.<ref name="ExpStation2"/> It initially hoped to raise one million dollars;<ref name="ExpStation3"/> in 1903, after raising $50,000 (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|50000|1903}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) of a hoped-for $150,000 (${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|150000|1903}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}) to operate the school, director George Powell announced that it would close and the property would be sold. Cutting presented a plan to the [[New Hampshire College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts]] to carry out the plan devised for the school in Poughkeepsie.<ref name="Closed"/> In 1908, school funds were donated to [[Cornell University]] as the Agricultural Student Loan Fund for students in Cornell's [[Cornell University College of Agriculture and Life Sciences|College of Agriculture and Life Sciences]].<ref name="CornellFund"/>
From 1903 to 1905 the original school building was known as Pocantico Lodge, a small year-round hotel. In 1905 Alice Knox, an employee at [[Mrs. Dow's School]], opened Miss Knox's School in the building.<!--Fire at 6:10 at night, students evacuated, unknown cause. 3-story frame structure with two wings running back of the main building. A bus carried the students to Mrs. Dow's and the [[Holbrook School]] and Dr. Wilder's residence. The Ossining Democratic Register reported that the fire was one of the largest that had been known to have occurred in the area. BMFD 2001 book--> Destroyed by fire in 1912, the school moved to nearby Tarrytown and then to [[Cooperstown]].<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=38}} The Knox School moved to [[St. James, New York|St. James]], on [[Long Island]], in 1954.<ref name="KnoxSchool"/> The only remaining feature of the Pocantico Lodge building is a stone retaining wall in front of the current building on the site, built in 1925 by Oscar Vatet for Rufus P. Johnston (pastor of [[John D. Rockefeller]]'s Fifth Avenue Baptist Church)<!--or [[Harry Emerson Fosdick]], according to WestPictHistp183-->. The building, later occupied by Arthur O'Connor, Cognitronics, and Frank B. Hall, is currently an unused part of Briarcliff Corporate Campus.<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=71, 73}}
==Farm status== [[File:St. Theresa's rectory.jpg|thumb|alt=A square two-story yellow house|The original farmhouse, now the rectory of St. Theresa's Catholic Church]] Most of the Pine Plains farmland is occupied by Berkshire Stud, a Thoroughbred breeding farm which purchased {{convert|550|acre|ha}} beginning in 1983,<ref name="BerkHistory"/> and the Mashomack Polo Club (which owns the farmhouse on Halcyon Lake).<ref name="LittleNine"/><ref name="BerkRealEstate"/> The farm's creamery<ref name="LittleNine"/> and several barns (some built during the 19th century) still stand at the polo club, and have been used since the 1980s for stables, farm-equipment storage and the raising of sporting birds. The barns also housed the Triangle Arts Association (part of the [[Triangle Arts Trust]]) from 1982 to 1993.<ref name="Mashomack"/><ref name="Triangle"/>
In Briarcliff Manor, part of the original Stillman farmhouse survives as the [[rectory]] of St. Theresa's Catholic Church<ref name="Changing Landscape"/>{{rp|page=79}} and several employee wood-framed cottages still stand on Dalmeny and Old Briarcliff Roads.<ref name="BMSHSNews2014"/> Similar houses are on South State, Pleasantville, and Poplar Roads. The farm's dairy building is owned by [[Consolidated Edison]]; the company also owns a nearby building which formerly housed the Briarcliff Manor Light and Power Company. The Plasmon Company of America's Woodside Avenue factory is now an [[automotive restoration]] facility.<ref name="LodgeBook"/>{{rp|pages=18, 125}} {{-}}

{{for|the Canadian public school|Brookhouse Elementary School}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox school |name = Brookhouse School |native_name = |latin_name = |image = Brookhouse_International_School_Nairobi_seal.gif |imagesize =100px |location = |streetaddress = Magadi Road, Langata |region = [[Nairobi]] |city = |state = |province = |county = |postcode = |postalcode = |zipcode = |country = [[Kenya]] |country1 = |coordinates = |schoolnumber = |schoolboard = |district = |authority = |religion = |denomination = |oversight = |affiliation = |superintendent = |trustee = |founder = |specialist = |president = |head of school = |headteacher = |head_label = |head = |chairperson = |principal = |head_name2 = |head2 = |dean = |administrator = |rector = |chaplain = |director = John O'Connor |staff = 130 (approx) |ranking = |bar pass rate = |faculty = |teaching_staff = |roll = |MOE = |ceeb = |school code = |LEA = |ofsted = |testaverage = |testname = |national_ranking = |classes = |classes offered = |avg_class_size = |SAT = |ACT = |graduates = |gender = Co-educational |lower_age = |upper_age = |houses =Four: Tsavo (yellow), Mara (blue), Samburu (green), Amboseli (red) |type = Independent day and [[boarding school]] |system = |fees = |tuition = |revenue = |endowment = |budget = |enrolment = |products = |grades = [[Pre-school]] through [[Year 13]]{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/About.html|work=brookhouse.ac.ke|publisher=Brookhouse International School|accessdate=2 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112090217/http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/About.html|archivedate=12 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} |age range = 2–19 years old |medium = |language = |classrooms = |campus = |campus size = |campus type = Suburban, adjacent to [[Nairobi National Park]] |hours_in_day = |athletics = |conference = |slogan = |song = |motto = ''Floreat Sapientia''
("Let Wisdom Flourish") |accreditation = |rival = |mascot = |mascot image = |sports = |patron = |team_name = |nickname = |school_colors = {{color box|Black}} {{color box|red}} {{color box|gold}} Black, Red and Gold |yearbook = |publication = |newspaper = |opened = |established = 1981 |founded = |status = |closed = |students = 550 (approx) |sixth_form_students = |pupils = |alumni = |nobel_laureates = |enrollment = |ratio = |gradeK = |grade1 = |grade2 = |grade3 = |grade4 = |grade5 = |grade6 = |grade7 = |grade8 = |grade9 = |grade10 = |grade11 = |grade12 = |grade13 = |other_grade_label = |other = |communities = |feeders = |free_label = |free_text = |free_label1 = |free_text1 = |free_label2 = |free_text2 = |free_label3 = |free_text3 = |free_label4 = |free_text4 = |free_label5 = |free_text5 = |footnotes = |homepage = [http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/ www.brookhouse.ac.ke] }} '''Brookhouse School''' (also known as '''Brookhouse International School''') is an independent British curriculum co-educational day and boarding school offering Early Years, preparatory and secondary schooling. It is located in [[Langata]], a suburb of [[Nairobi]], about {{convert|10|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} from the Nairobi's CBD. The school was opened in 1981 and caters for pupils from pre-school to [[A-level]], with an overall enrolment of 750 students. The campus occupies a {{convert|14|acre|adj=on|sigfig=2}} site, adjacent to the [[Nairobi National Park]].[[File:SixthForm.JPG|440px|right]] ==Academics== Brookhouse follows the British National Curriculum and students take [[IGCSE]] and [[A-Level]] at 16+ and 18+, respectively. Students take examinations through both the [[Cambridge International Examinations]] (CIE){{cite web| url=http://www.cie.org.uk/events/detail?event_id=34710&nes=0| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101229034719/http://www.cie.org.uk/events/detail?event_id=34710&nes=0| archivedate=29 December 2010|title= Events: Stage 2 Professional Development Courses, Kenya| publisher= Cambridge International Examinations|accessdate=March 20, 2016| deadurl= yes}} and [[Edexcel]] Boards. Most students elect to continue their education at UK universities, with an increasing number of students going to the USA, Canada, Australia and South Africa for post-secondary education. The school offers [[English as a Second Language]] (ESL) and Special Needs support. ==Admission== The academic year begins in late August for Term 1. Entry to the school is preferable at that time but students may be accepted at any time in the year. Acceptance follows an evaluation of the child's previous academic record. Entry assessment tests are used to assist in the placement process. All admissions to Brookhouse School are made through a senior member of staff. When seeking admission, prospective students are requested to provide copies of previous school reports, academic transcripts, and where applicable, a Leaving Certificate. Where practicable, prospective students will also be interviewed and may be asked to sit an entrance placement examination. A student will only be admitted to Brookhouse if it is considered that they will benefit from the curriculum offered and if they are prepared to contribute positively to the life of the school. Students come from 40 different countries.{{cite web|title=Application and Admission|url=http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/application.html|work=brookhouse.ac.ke|publisher=Brookhouse International School|accessdate=2 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116064458/http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/application.html|archivedate=16 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Brookhouse International School|url=http://eaprivateschools.com/schools/?school_id=11&search=1|publisher=The East African Private Schools Guide|accessdate=2 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201150857/http://eaprivateschools.com/schools/?school_id=11&search=1|archivedate=1 February 2011|df=dmy-all}} ==Facilities== *'''Boarding House''' – The school has the capacity for nearly 200 boarders to live on site, all housed in purpose-built accommodation. There are separate wings for boys and girls. A dozen or more staff are also accommodated on site, to provide a high level of supervision and support for the boarding students. The Boarding House has its own student common rooms and other recreational facilities. Younger children are accommodated in a separate area of the Boarding complex.They have their own full-time boarding staff to provide a homely atmosphere for the children. *'''Sports''' – Brookhouse has a gym that all students can use under the supervision of the gym coach. In 2010, the Tergat Sports Centre was officially opened. Named after one of Kenya's long distance athletic greats, [[Paul Tergat]], the indoor sports centre hosts major indoor sports and activities. *'''Auditorium''' – The on-campus Burudani Theatre is a world-class performing arts venue for music concerts, drama performances and other activities. In 2013 it was the venue for the historic inaugural presidential debates in the run up to the [[Kenyan presidential election, 2013]] March. ==Curriculum== [[File:Music at Brookhouse.jpg|400px|right]] Brookhouse School follows an adapted form of the British National Curriculum. The Early Years Unit caters for children aged 2–5 years, providing a carefully planned induction to the British National Curriculum. Throughout the Preparatory School up to and including Year Eight students study the set national curriculum subjects, including Mathematics, English, Science, Geography, History, Art, Physical Education, Music, a modern Foreign Language and [[information and communications technology]] (ICT). The Secondary section of the school commences with the one year Pre-IGCSE Year 9 programme, leading to the two years of the IGCSE course during Year's 10 and 11. Upon successful completion of the IGCSE examinations pupils can progress to take their AS and A-level courses in Year's 12 and 13, before moving on to universities across the globe. The school also offers an [[international foundation year]] (IFY) bridging programme in partnership with the Northern Consortium of UK Universities (NCUK){{cite web|title=Northern Consortium of UK Universities| url= http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/foundation.html| website= brookhouse.ac.ke| publisher=Brookhouse International School| accessdate= March 20, 2016| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131026060729/http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke/foundation.html| archivedate=26 October 2013| deadurl= yes}} and specialist vocational [[Business and Technician Education Council]] (BTEC) courses in Music, Music Technology and Art & Design. ==Extracurricular activities== Brookhouse School offers an extensive programme of extra-curricular activities, including a wide range of sports and trips. Examples of activities regularly offered at Brookhouse are: *''[[Round Square (educational organisation)|Round Square]]''{{cite web|title=Round Square|url=http://www.roundsquare.org/index.php?id=592|work=Round Square|publisher=Round Square|accessdate=2 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130118001757/http://www.roundsquare.org/index.php?id=592|archivedate=18 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} Community Service projects *President's Award Scheme *Model United Nations[[File:School Library.jpg|400px|right]] *LAMDA, drama, debating and verse speaking *Choir, orchestra and other ensemble musical groups *Individual musical instrument tuition *Camping and outdoor adventure activities *Environment and wildlife clubs *Horse-riding, archery and Martial Arts clubs *Aerobics and Gym *Desktop publishing and magazine production *Electronics, Robotics and Science Discovery *First Aid *Chess and Board Games *Various craft and cooking clubs ==Round Square== [[Round Square (educational organisation)|Round Square]] is a worldwide association of schools sharing unique and ambitious goals. Students attending Round Square schools on five continents. They make a strong commitment, beyond academic excellence, to personal development and responsibility. This is achieved by participating in community service, work projects, exchange programmes and outdoor adventure activities. Brookhouse is a global member of the Round Square organisation. The school participates in student exchanges with other Round Square schools around the globe, attends Round Square conferences in different parts of the world, and participates in Round Square International Service (RSIS) projects. In April 2012 Brookhouse School hosted the international Round Square conference. ==Sport== The main sporting activities at Brookhouse include: [[File:Sports at Brookhouse.jpg|400px|right]] *basketball *soccer *swimming *athletics *[[rugby football|rugby]] *[[rounders]] *[[netball]] *[[field hockey]] *tennis *golf *[[cricket]] These sports are spread across the three terms of the school year. Contact with other independent schools in Kenya is maintained by means of a full fixture list of inter-school matches in all the major sports at different age levels. In addition there is active participation in tournaments, competitions, festivals, leagues and exhibitions. There are Inter-House competitions in cross-country, athletics, basketball, rounders, soccer, netball, rugby and swimming. The extensive fitness centre allows opportunities for general fitness in the gym, aerobics sessions and weights training. ==Reputation== The school was selected for review by the [[Good Schools Guide]] International and is a member of the prestigious [[G20]] Schools. The school is fully accredited by the Council of International Schools (CIS){{cite web|title=CIS|url=http://www.cois.org/page.cfm?p=801|registration=yes| publisher=Council of International Schools| accessdate= 2 March 2013}} and the Independent Association of Preparatory Schools (IAPS).{{cite web|title=IAPS|url=https://www.iaps.org.uk/|publisher=Independent Association of Preparatory Schools| registration= yes| accessdate=2 March 2013}} ==Alumni== The Brookhouse community (alumni and staff) includes: *Dr. [[Louise Leakey]], palaeontologist, educator and lecturer{{cite web|title=Dr Louise Leakey|url=http://leakeyfoundation.org/about-us/leakey-family/|work=LeakeyFoundation.org|accessdate=2 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315150444/http://leakeyfoundation.org/about-us/leakey-family/|archivedate=15 March 2013|df=dmy-all}} *[[Liza Mucheru-Wisner]], a finalist in the tenth season of the reality TV show contest [[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|''The Apprentice'' (US version)]]{{cite web|title=Liza Mucheru-Wisner| url=http://www.nation.co.ke/News/Donald-Trumps-apprentice-comes-home-/-/1056/1058596/-/15hkajuz/-/index.html| work= [[Daily Nation]]|accessdate=2 March 2013}} *[[E-Sir]] (1981–2003), musician *The Moipei Quartet, 2006 [[UNICEF]] Child Ambassadors and Head of State Commendation recipients from the [[President of Kenya]] *[[Emanuel Jal]], hip-hop artist and humanitarian advocate *Richard Turere, inventor of the [[lion lights]]{{cite web|title=Richard Turere| url= http://newswatch.nationalgeographic.com/2013/02/27/lions-no-match-for-young-boy-and-his-invention-richard-turere-at-ted/|work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|accessdate=8 April 2013}} and [[TED (conference)|TED]] 2013 speaker *[[Eric Wainaina (musician)|Eric Wainaina]], musician and playwright *Ian Mbugua, actor and musician *Kevin Mbugua, musician{{cite web|title=Kevin Mbugua|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/Features/buzz/Kevin-Samuel/-/441236/1682326/-/wq9405/-/index.html|work=Daily Nation|publisher=Daily Nation|accessdate=2 March 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{portal|Schools}} *[http://www.brookhouse.ac.ke Official website] {{Coord|1|20|46|S|36|45|54|E|type:edu|display=title}} [[Category:Schools in Kenya]] [[Category:Education in Nairobi]] [[Category:International schools in Kenya]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Kenya]]

{{Infobox television channel | name = Canal Educativo | logofile = | logosize = | logocaption = | logoalt = | logo2 = | launch = {{Start date and age|2002|5|9}} | closed date = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | picture format = | share = | share as of = | share source = | network = | owner = | parent = | slogan = Donde siempre se aprende... | motto = | country = | language = | broadcast area = | affiliates = | headquarters = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | former names = | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = | timeshift names = | website = {{URL|www.tvcubana.icrt.cu}} | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = [[Hispasat|Hispasat 1D]] <small>Americas</small> | sat chan 1 = 11884 V / 27500 / 3/4 | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }}
'''Canal Educativo''' is a [[Television in Cuba|Cuban television]] channel devoted to educational programming. Operated by the [[Cuban Institute of Radio and Television|ICRT]], it began operations on 9 May 2002.
==History== Prior to the establishment of Canal Educativo, there was no designated home for educational programming among Cuba's national television portfolio. The establishment of this network enabled the delivery of telecourses and the use of school hours to broadcast content. Canal Educativo covers 87.9% of the Cuban population.
In 2004, a second network, '''Canal Educativo 2''' (currently abbreviated '''ce2''' on air), was launched.
==Programming== Canal Educativo's programming includes telecourses, documentaries, historical programs, and arts programming including opera, ballet and musical performances. It also reportedly airs cartoons such as ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''.
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2013}}
[[Category:Television in Cuba]] [[Category:Education in Cuba]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2002]]

page.title: Centre for Research and Action for Peace

revision.text:
{{third-party|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox organization | name = Centre for Research and
Action for Peace | former name = African Institute for Economic and Social Development (INADES) | image =CentResActPeace.png | image_border = | size = 180 | alt = | caption = | abbreviation = CERAP | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = | extinction = | merger = | merged = | established = {{Start date and age| 1962 }} | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = 15 avenue Jean Mermoz Cocody
08 bp 2088 [[Abidjan]] 08
[[Ivory Coast]] | coords = | region_served = | membership = | language = French | general = | leader_title = Managing Director | leader_name = Francis P. Kabore{{fr}} [http://cerap-inades.org/ Organization] | leader_title2 = Director of DIHR | leader_name2 = Ludovic Lado | leader_title3 = Program coordinators | leader_name3 = Aristide Dossou
Rodrigue Naortangar | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[Jesuit]], [[Catholic church|Catholic]] | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{fr}} [http://cerap-inades.org/ CERAP] }} '''Centre for Research and Action for Peace (CERAP)''' (''Centre de Recherche et d'Action pour la Paix''), Ivory Coast, began as the African Institute for Economic and Social Development (INADES), with its early focus on agricultural training. In 2003, INADES expanded and changed its name to CERAP. ==History== The CERAP was established in 1962 at the request of the Catholic bishops of West Africa to develop a center of Christian reflection on socio-economic development, with the cooperation of a similar center in France (CERAS),{{Cite web|url=http://www.sjweb.info/sjs/pjnew/PJShow.cfm?pubTextID=9048|title=Social Justice Secretariat|website=www.sjweb.info|language=en|access-date=2017-10-18}} and with the encouragement of political leaders in the Ivory Coast including President [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny]].{{fact|date=April 2018}} ==Programs== On 9 May 2003, INADES changed its name to CERAP, Centre for Research and Action for Peace, and reorganized into four branches: * CEDOC, created in 1964 under the name of IDOC, is the Documentation Centre for the social sciences. * Social Action in Urban Areas (ASMU), created in 1985, offers apprenticeships for disadvantaged youth. * EDICERAP, formerly INADES-Editions (1976-1992), encourages publication of newspapers and books by Ivorian authors. It also publishes the monthly ''Courrier Débats – West Africa''. * The Institute of Dignity and Human Rights (DIHR), created in 2003, grants diplomas and the master's degree in human rights, peace studies, economic ethics, and sustainable development, recognized by the Ivorian Ministry of Higher Education.Decree No. 489 / MES / DESUP of 5 October 2005 ==References== {{Reflist|3}} [[Category:Education in Ivory Coast]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1962]] [[Category:Jesuit development centres]]
